data.question:
What thread-safety guarantee does ConcurrentHashMap's compute() method provide for the remapping function?

	- Atomic execution per key
	- Process-wide exclusivity
	- Only single-writer guarantee
	- No guarantees under high contention
data.explanation:
Title: CHM Atomic Computations

Locks only the affected hash bucket during compute(), allowing concurrent operations on other keys.

Example 1:
map.compute(key, (k,v) -> v+1); // Atomic for this key

Example 2:
// Internal implementation:
synchronized (f) { // Node lock
  if (tabAt(tab, i) == f) ...

Example 3:
// Concurrent update:
map.compute(keyA, ...); // Runs concurrently with
map.compute(keyB, ...);

data.question:
What critical difference exists between Vector and Collections.synchronizedList(new ArrayList())?

	- Vector synchronizes per method while synchronizedList uses a mutex
	- Only Vector supports concurrent iteration
	- synchronizedList has better memory locality
	- Vector uses copy-on-write internally

What internal mechanism triggers ArrayList's ConcurrentModificationException during structural modifications?

	- Version counter in AbstractList
	- Hash code verification
	- Iterator's expectedModCount field
	- Thread-local modification stamps

When does WeakHashMap automatically purge entries after key garbage collection?

	- During next put/get operation
	- Immediately via ReferenceQueue
	- Only during full GC cycles
	- When explicitly calling size()

What distinguishes ConcurrentLinkedQueue's poll() from peek() in terms of thread visibility guarantees?

	- poll() provides happens-before for element removal
	- Both offer identical visibility
	- peek() forces memory barriers
	- Only poll() reads volatile fields

Why does Collections.synchronizedMap() exhibit poor throughput for entrySet() iteration under contention?

	- Requires global lock on entire map
	- Creates defensive copies of all entries
	- Uses fine-grained locking per entry
	- Lacks iterator fail-fast behavior

What is the time complexity for ConcurrentSkipListMap's put() operation compared to ConcurrentHashMap?

	- O(log n) vs O(1) average case
	- O(1) vs O(n) worst case
	- Both O(1) with different constants
	- O(n) vs O(log n) for large datasets

What memory visibility guarantees does LinkedBlockingQueue provide between producer and consumer threads?

	- Happens-before for items put before take
	- Only eventual consistency
	- Requires explicit synchronization
	- Visibility limited to queue size changes

Why does CopyOnWriteArrayList's iterator never throw ConcurrentModificationException?

	- Uses a snapshot of the backing array
	- Implements deep cloning for each element
	- Synchronizes all iterator operations
	- Maintains a version counter for validation

In Java 8+, how does ConcurrentHashMap's internal segmentation differ from pre-Java 8 implementations?

	- Uses synchronized blocks per bucket instead of ReentrantLocks
	- Replaces segments with fine-grained node-level locking
	- Implements a global lock for all write operations
	- Removes synchronization entirely for read operations

What is the compile-time type of `var list = Arrays.asList(1, 2.0)` in Java 10+?

	- `List<Integer>`
	- `List<Number>`
	- `List<Object>`
	- `List<Double>`
data.explanation:
Title: `var` and Generic Inference

`var` inherits the most specific common supertype (Number for Integer and Double).

Example 1:
var list = Arrays.asList(1, 2.0); // List<Number>

Example 2:
var mixed = Arrays.asList("text", 42); // List<Serializable & Comparable>

Example 3:
// Explicit type needed for clarity
List<Number> nums = Arrays.asList(1, 2.0);

data.question:
How does the JVM represent `boolean` values in memory at runtime?

	- As 1-bit flags
	- Using full bytes
	- Depends on JVM implementation
	- Always as integer 0/1
data.explanation:
Title: Boolean Storage Variability

The JVM spec doesn't mandate a size‚ÄîHotSpot uses 1 byte per boolean, but arrays may pack them.

Example 1:
boolean b = true; // Typically 1 byte

Example 2:
boolean[] arr = new boolean[100]; // May use 1 bit per element

Example 3:
// JNI interaction
native void setFlag(boolean flag); // JVM-dependent ABI

data.question:
Why can't Java `char` type represent all Unicode characters despite using UTF-16?

	- Some codepoints require surrogate pairs
	- JVM uses ASCII internally
	- `char` is only 8-bit
	- Unicode standards prohibit it
data.explanation:
Title: Unicode Character Representation

UTF-16 uses 2 `char`s (surrogate pairs) for codepoints beyond BMP (Basic Multilingual Plane).

Example 1:
char c = 'ùÑû'; // Compile error (U+1D11E needs 2 chars)

Example 2:
// Correct representation
String s = "ùÑû"; // Length=2 (surrogate pair)

Example 3:
// Codepoint handling
int cp = s.codePointAt(0); // Returns 0x1D11E

data.question:
What is the performance implication of `BigInteger`'s immutability for repeated arithmetic operations?

	- Requires object recreation
	- Enables thread safety
	- Allows JIT optimizations
	- Reduces garbage collection

Why do enums consume more memory than integer constants despite similar functionality?

	- Each value is a full object
	- JVM stores metadata for reflection
	- Requires additional hash tables
	- All enum values are strings internally

How can varargs methods cause heap pollution warnings with generic types?

	- By forcing type erasure
	- Allowing non-reifiable types in arrays
	- Disabling JIT optimizations
	- Requiring explicit type parameters

What causes a `NullPointerException` when unboxing an `Integer` to `int`?

	- Automatic type conversion failure
	- Null value in Integer object
	- Arithmetic overflow
	- Compiler optimization bug

What is the output of `System.out.println(0.1 + 0.2 == 0.3)` and why?

	- `true` due to exact binary representation
	- `false` because of floating-point rounding
	- Compile error
	- Depends on JVM implementation

Why does concatenating strings in a loop with `+` operator degrade performance?

	- Creates intermediate String objects
	- JVM optimizes it automatically
	- Uses constant pool efficiently
	- No performance impact in modern Java

What is the key difference in memory usage between `int` and `Integer` when stored in an `ArrayList`?

	- Primitive `int` uses stack memory
	- `Integer` objects are heap-allocated
	- Autoboxing overhead occurs with `Integer`
	- Both behave identically in collections
data.explanation:
Title: Memory Impact of Wrapper Classes

Primitives like `int` use stack memory, while `Integer` objects require heap allocation, increasing GC pressure and memory overhead.

Example 1:
ArrayList<Integer> list = new ArrayList<>();
list.add(42); // Heap allocation for Integer.valueOf(42)

Example 2:
int[] arr = new int[1000]; // Contiguous stack memory

Example 3:
// Autoboxing overhead
for (int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) list.add(i); // 1000 Integer objects

data.question:
What is the primary advantage of java.util.concurrent collections over synchronized wrappers?

Options:
A) Lower contention via fine-grained locking
B) Built-in transaction support
C) Guaranteed deadlock avoidance
D) All of the above

Code:
Map<String, Integer> syncMap = Collections.synchronizedMap(new HashMap<>());
ConcurrentHashMap<String, Integer> concurrentMap = new ConcurrentHashMap<>();
data.explanation:
Title: Concurrent Collection Benefits

java.util.concurrent uses lock striping (e.g., CHM), CAS operations, or copy-on-write for higher throughput under contention vs. global locks.

Example 1:
// High contention (synchronizedMap)
syncMap.get(k); // Blocks all other operations

Example 2:
// Lower contention (CHM)
concurrentMap.get(k); // Non-blocking

Example 3:
// Write performance
concurrentMap.put(k, v); // Locks only one bucket

data.question:
When does WeakHashMap automatically remove entries?

Options:
A) When the key is garbage collected
B) When the value is garbage collected
C) After a timeout
D) During full GC only

Code:
WeakHashMap<Key, Value> map = new WeakHashMap<>();
map.put(new Key(), new Value());
System.gc(); // Key becomes eligible for GC
options: When the key is garbage collected
When the value is garbage collected
data.response: When the key is garbage collected

data.question:
How can a single-threaded application trigger ConcurrentModificationException with an ArrayList?

Options:
A) Using remove() during iteration
B) Calling size() during iteration
C) Using parallelStream()
D) All of the above

Code:
List<String> list = new ArrayList<>(List.of("A", "B"));
for (String s : list) {
  list.remove(s); // Throws CME
}

What distinguishes Vector from Collections.synchronizedList(new ArrayList<>())?

Options:
A) Vector synchronizes per method
B) Vector has dynamic growth
C) Vector is thread-safe
D) Nothing, they are equivalent

Code:
Vector<String> vec = new Vector<>();
List<String> syncList = Collections.synchronizedList(new ArrayList<>());

What operation on a synchronizedMap is NOT thread-safe without external synchronization?

Options:
A) map.put()
B) map.get()
C) map.containsKey() + map.putIfAbsent()
D) map.size()

Code:
Map<String, Integer> syncMap = Collections.synchronizedMap(new HashMap<>());
if (!syncMap.containsKey("k")) {
  syncMap.put("k", 1); // Race condition
}

data.explanation:
Title: Backpressure with BlockingQueue

ArrayBlockingQueue's fixed size enforces backpressure (producers block when full). LinkedBlockingQueue may grow unbounded, risking OOM.

Example 1:
// Unbounded risk (LinkedBlockingQueue)
new LinkedBlockingQueue<>(); // May grow indefinitely

Example 2:
// Bounded (ArrayBlockingQueue)
new ArrayBlockingQueue<>(100); // Safe backpressure

Example 3:
// Extreme (SynchronousQueue)
new SynchronousQueue(); // No buffering, direct handoff

When should CopyOnWriteArrayList be avoided despite its thread safety?

Options:
A) Frequent write operations
B) Large datasets
C) Real-time latency requirements
D) All of the above

Code:
CopyOnWriteArrayList<Integer> list = new CopyOnWriteArrayList<>();
list.add(1); // Creates a new internal array

How can `ThreadLocal` cause memory leaks in web applications?

Options:
A) Thread reuse in pools
B) Missing `remove()` calls
C) Strong references to classes
D) All of the above

Code:
ThreadLocal<User> userContext = new ThreadLocal<>();
userContext.set(currentUser);

Which method is most likely to be inlined by the JIT compiler?

Options:
A) Large recursive method
B) Small `private static` method
C) Method with `synchronized` block
D) Virtual method with multiple overrides

Code:
private static int add(int a, int b) { return a + b; }
synchronized void update() { ... }

Which list implementation is immutable and memory-efficient?

Options:
A) `List.of()`
B) `Arrays.asList()`
C) `new ArrayList<>()`
D) `Collections.emptyList()`

Code:
List<String> l1 = List.of("a", "b");
List<String> l2 = Arrays.asList("a", "b");

When should `AtomicInteger` be preferred over `volatile int`?

Options:
A) For read-heavy workloads
B) For compound actions (e.g., `i++`)
C) When memory visibility is sufficient
D) Never

Code:
volatile int counter1 = 0;
AtomicInteger counter2 = new AtomicInteger(0);
data.explanation:
Title: Atomicity vs. Visibility

`volatile` ensures visibility but not atomicity (e.g., `counter++` is non-atomic).
`AtomicInteger` provides CAS-based atomic operations.

Example 1:
// Unsafe with volatile
counter1++; // Race condition

Example 2:
// Safe with AtomicInteger
counter2.incrementAndGet(); // Atomic

Example 3:
// Read-only (volatile is enough)
if (counter1 > 0) { ... } // Safe for visibility

data.question:
Which JVM flag controls the size of the G1 Heap regions?

Options:
A) `-XX:G1HeapRegionSize`
B) `-Xmn`
C) `-XX:NewSize`
D) `-XX:SurvivorRatio`

Code:
// JVM args for G1 GC
// -XX:+UseG1GC -XX:G1HeapRegionSize=2M
data.explanation:
Title: G1 Heap Region Configuration

`-XX:G1HeapRegionSize` sets the size (1MB‚Äì32MB) of G1 regions.
`-Xmn` sets young gen size; `SurvivorRatio` adjusts Eden/Survivor.

Example 1:
// 4MB regions (default is ergonomic)
-XX:G1HeapRegionSize=4M

Example 2:
// Too small (overhead)
-XX:G1HeapRegionSize=1M // May increase GC pauses

Example 3:
// Too large (waste)
-XX:G1HeapRegionSize=32M // Poor heap utilization

data.question:
Why does `ArrayList<Integer>` perform worse than `int[]` for large datasets?

Options:
A) Boxing overhead
B) Memory fragmentation
C) Cache misses
D) All of the above

Code:
List<Integer> list = new ArrayList<>();
int[] arr = new int[1_000_000];
data.explanation:
Title: Primitive vs. Boxed Performance

`ArrayList<Integer>` stores objects (heap allocation), causing boxing/unboxing overhead, memory fragmentation, and cache inefficiency.
`int[]` uses contiguous primitive data.

Example 1:
// Boxing overhead
list.add(42); // Implicit Integer.valueOf(42)
int x = list.get(0); // Implicit list.get(0).intValue()

Example 2:
// Memory access
for (int i : arr) { ... } // Contiguous memory
for (int i : list) { ... } // Pointer chasing

Example 3:
// Cache locality test
Arrays.fill(arr, 1); // Faster than
list.forEach(i -> list.set(i, 1));
Java promotes the int to double before addition. So 10 + 3.5 results in 13.5.

data.question: Which control flow statement is best suited for iterating over an array?
data.explanation: `for` loops are ideal for iterating through arrays when the index is known.
String is immutable, and `concat()` returns a new string. The assignment updates `s`.

data.question: Which keyword is used to define a method that returns nothing in Java?
data.explanation: `void` is used to define methods that return no value in Java.

data.topic: Classes, Objects, and OOP (Inheritance, Polymorphism, Encapsulation, Abstraction)
data.question: Which concept allows objects to take many forms?
data.explanation: Polymorphism enables a method to perform differently based on the object.

data.question: Which statement correctly defines a Java interface?
data.explanation: Java uses the `interface` keyword to declare interfaces.

data.question: What is the base class for all exceptions in Java?
data.explanation: `Throwable` is the superclass of all exceptions and errors in Java.

data.question: Which collection maintains insertion order and allows duplicates?
data.explanation: `ArrayList` maintains insertion order and allows duplicates.

data.question: Which class is used to write text to a file in Java?
data.explanation: `FileWriter` writes character data to files.

data.question: Which method starts a thread in Java?
data.explanation: `start()` launches a new thread and calls `run()` internally.

data.question: Which statement defines a functional interface in Java?
options:
@FunctionalInterface
interface Converter<T, R> { R convert(T t); }
interface Predicate { boolean test(); void reset(); }
data.response:
@FunctionalInterface
interface Converter<T, R> { R convert(T t); }
data.explanation: A functional interface contains only one abstract method. The @FunctionalInterface annotation is optional but recommended.
Optional.of("Java") is not empty, so orElse returns "Java" instead of the fallback.

data.question: Which class is used to analyze annotations at runtime?
data.explanation: Java uses reflection via the Class object to inspect annotations using methods like getAnnotation() and isAnnotationPresent().

data.question: What is the effect of marking a field `static final`?
data.explanation: `static` makes a field class-level, and `final` makes it immutable‚Äîtogether forming a constant shared across all instances.

data.question: What is a non-static inner class called in Java?
data.explanation: A non-static inner class defined inside another class is called a member class and needs an outer instance.

data.question: What keyword is used to import a class from another package?
data.explanation: `import` allows classes from other packages to be referenced in your code.

data.topic: JVM, Memory Model, and Garbage Collection
data.question: Which part of memory is used to store class metadata in JVM?
data.explanation: Class metadata is stored in PermGen (Java 7 and earlier) or MetaSpace (Java 8+), separate from the heap.

data.question: Which interface is used to execute SQL queries in JDBC?
data.explanation: The Statement interface sends SQL commands to the database, and results are retrieved via ResultSet.

data.question: Which JUnit annotation is used to run code before each test method?
data.explanation: `@BeforeEach` is used in JUnit 5 to specify methods that run before every test method.

data.question: Which statement correctly defines a Java Record?
options: @Data class Person { String name; int age; }
data class Person(String name, int age)
data.explanation: Records, introduced in Java 14+, are concise syntax for immutable data carriers using the `record` keyword.

Stream multiplies each number by 2: 2 + 4 + 6 = 12.
Dividing by zero throws ArithmeticException, which is caught and handled.
Dynamic method dispatch resolves to class B's version of `show`.

data.question:
What does this write to file?

Files.write(Paths.get("test.txt"), "Hello".getBytes());
data.explanation: The `Files.write` method writes byte content to the given path.

data.question:
What does this thread print?

new Thread(() -> System.out.println("Hello from thread")).start();
data.explanation: This lambda-based thread prints once when run asynchronously.
Switch expressions introduced in Java 14 allow concise arrow-based cases.
`orElse()` returns fallback when the Optional is empty.

data.question: Which access modifier allows visibility within the same package only?
data.explanation: If no modifier is specified, Java assumes default (package-private) access.
Generics enforce type safety. get(0) returns the string added.

The modulo (%) operator returns the remainder of division between two integers. In this case, `31 % 4` equals 3.

Examples:
1. `int a = 10, b = 3;` ‚Üí Output: 1 (10 / 3 = 3 R1)
2. `int a = 8, b = 2;` ‚Üí Output: 0 (8 is divisible by 2)
3. `int a = 7, b = 5;` ‚Üí Output: 2 (7 / 5 = 1 R2)
4. `int a = 15, b = 4;` ‚Üí Output: 3 (15 / 4 = 3 R3)
// Useful in hashing, loops, and buffer rotation.

Any number modulo 1 returns 0, since there is no remainder.

Examples:
1. `int a = 5, b = 1;` ‚Üí Output: 0
2. `int a = 100, b = 1;` ‚Üí Output: 0
3. `int a = -10, b = 1;` ‚Üí Output: 0
4. `int a = 0, b = 1;` ‚Üí Output: 0
// Useful in fixed-size window computations.

`33 % 2` returns 1 because 33 divided by 2 gives a remainder of 1.

Examples:
1. `int a = 9, b = 2;` ‚Üí Output: 1
2. `int a = 13, b = 2;` ‚Üí Output: 1
3. `int a = 4, b = 2;` ‚Üí Output: 0
4. `int a = 1, b = 2;` ‚Üí Output: 1
// Helpful in checking if a number is even or odd.

34 divided by 3 is 11 remainder 1, so 34 % 3 = 1.

Examples:
1. `int a = 17, b = 3;` ‚Üí Output: 2
2. `int a = 30, b = 3;` ‚Üí Output: 0
3. `int a = 4, b = 3;` ‚Üí Output: 1
4. `int a = 1, b = 3;` ‚Üí Output: 1
// Used in modulo arithmetic and offset calculation.

`35 % 4` yields 3 because 4 * 8 = 32 and 35 - 32 = 3.

Examples:
1. `int a = 9, b = 4;` ‚Üí Output: 1
2. `int a = 8, b = 4;` ‚Üí Output: 0
3. `int a = 5, b = 4;` ‚Üí Output: 1
4. `int a = 12, b = 4;` ‚Üí Output: 0
// Often used in wrap-around operations like clocks or circular buffers.

Any number modulo 1 is always 0 since every integer is divisible by 1.

Examples:
1. `int x = 25, y = 1;` ‚Üí Output: 0
2. `int x = -10, y = 1;` ‚Üí Output: 0
3. `int x = 0, y = 1;` ‚Üí Output: 0
4. `int x = 999, y = 1;` ‚Üí Output: 0
// Useful in simplifying repetitive patterns.

37 divided by 2 leaves a remainder of 1 (since 2 * 18 = 36).

Examples:
1. `int a = 5, b = 2;` ‚Üí Output: 1
2. `int a = 6, b = 2;` ‚Üí Output: 0
3. `int a = 13, b = 2;` ‚Üí Output: 1
4. `int a = 100, b = 2;` ‚Üí Output: 0
// Commonly used to check even/odd numbers.

`38 % 3` equals 2 because 3 * 12 = 36 and 38 - 36 = 2.

Examples:
1. `int a = 11, b = 3;` ‚Üí Output: 2
2. `int a = 12, b = 3;` ‚Üí Output: 0
3. `int a = 13, b = 3;` ‚Üí Output: 1
4. `int a = 14, b = 3;` ‚Üí Output: 2
// Useful in hashing and index distribution.

`39 % 4` yields 3 because 4 * 9 = 36, and 39 - 36 = 3.

Examples:
1. `int a = 15, b = 4;` ‚Üí Output: 3
2. `int a = 8, b = 4;` ‚Üí Output: 0
3. `int a = 9, b = 4;` ‚Üí Output: 1
4. `int a = 16, b = 4;` ‚Üí Output: 0
// Seen in scenarios where periodic overflow must be avoided.

Any integer modulo 1 always results in 0. Here, 40 % 1 = 0.

Examples:
1. `int x = 1 % 1;` ‚Üí Output: 0
2. `int x = 1000 % 1;` ‚Üí Output: 0
3. `int x = -50 % 1;` ‚Üí Output: 0
4. `int x = 99999 % 1;` ‚Üí Output: 0
// Use cases include normalizing indices and calendar rotations.

In Java, `byte` has a range from -128 to 127. When it overflows (127 + 1), it wraps around to -128 due to 2's complement representation.

Examples:
1. `byte b = 127; b++;` ‚Üí Output: -128
2. `byte b = -128; b--;` ‚Üí Output: 127
3. `byte b = 0; b--;` ‚Üí Output: -1
4. `byte b = -1; b++;` ‚Üí Output: 0
// Byte is an 8-bit signed integer. Overflow behavior is expected in bounded types.

Loop runs while i < 3. On first iteration, i=0 is printed. On second, i=1 triggers `break` before print.

Examples:
1. `while(i < 2) i++;` ‚Üí Loop runs twice
2. `for(int i=0; i<3; i++) { if(i==2) continue; }` ‚Üí skips i==2
3. `do {} while(i<3);` ‚Üí Executes once even if condition is false
4. `if (true) return;` ‚Üí Immediately exits method
// Control statements alter execution flow.

String is immutable. `concat()` returns a new string, but original `s` is unchanged unless reassigned.

Examples:
1. `s = s.concat("xyz")` ‚Üí Output: abcxyz
2. "hello".replace("h", "j") ‚Üí Output: jello
3. `char[] arr = {'a','b'}; new String(arr)` ‚Üí Output: ab
4. `String[] sa = new String[2]; sa[0] = "hi";` ‚Üí Indexed string = hi
// Always reassign string if you want to capture result.

`add` is a static method returning the sum of two integers. Examples:
1. add(1, 1) ‚Üí 2
2. add(0, 0) ‚Üí 0
3. add(-5, 5) ‚Üí 0
4. add(10, -3) ‚Üí 7
// Methods encapsulate logic and support reusability.

Object `obj` is an instance of class A. Examples:
1. new A().x ‚Üí 5
2. A obj = null; ‚Üí accessing obj.x causes NullPointerException
3. obj.x + 1 ‚Üí 6
4. obj.x = 10 ‚Üí modifies field
// Objects encapsulate state using fields.

Calling method on `null` throws NPE. Examples:
1. s = null; s.length() ‚Üí throws
2. catch (Exception e) ‚Üí catches all
3. finally ‚Üí always runs
4. throw new IOException() ‚Üí manual throw
// Try-catch prevents app crash.

Two elements are added. Examples:
1. list.add("X") ‚Üí size grows
2. list.clear() ‚Üí becomes 0
3. list.get(0) ‚Üí 'A'
4. list.contains("B") ‚Üí true
// Generics improve type safety.

data.question:
What does this code do?

Files.write(Paths.get("out.txt"), "data".getBytes());
data.explanation:
It writes byte data to a file. Examples:
1. Files.readAllLines(path) ‚Üí reads text
2. Files.exists(path) ‚Üí checks presence
3. Files.delete(path) ‚Üí removes file
4. Files.createFile(path) ‚Üí new file
// Java NIO simplifies I/O ops.

Creates a thread with a lambda Runnable. Examples:
1. new Thread(() -> {}).start() ‚Üí async
2. Thread.sleep(1000) ‚Üí pause
3. t.join() ‚Üí wait
4. ExecutorService ‚Üí thread pool
// Use for parallel tasks.

Lambda `x -> x * x` applied to 4 returns 16. Examples:
1. x -> x + 1 ‚Üí increment
2. (a, b) -> a + b ‚Üí sum
3. () -> 42 ‚Üí constant
4. str -> str.length() ‚Üí string length
// Introduced in Java 8.

Stream filters for 'b'. Examples:
1. map(String::toUpperCase) ‚Üí transforms
2. count() ‚Üí totals
3. findFirst().orElse("x") ‚Üí safe retrieval
4. sorted() ‚Üí orders
// Streams simplify data ops.

Checks if method has @Deprecated annotation. Examples:
1. @Override ‚Üí compiler validates
2. @Retention(RUNTIME) ‚Üí reflection visible
3. getAnnotations() ‚Üí lists
4. isAnnotationPresent(...) ‚Üí boolean
// Annotations add metadata.
`final` variables cannot be reassigned after initialization. Examples: final int x = 5 ‚Üí OK, x = 6 ‚Üí error. Useful for constants and immutability.
An inner class has access to its enclosing class. Must instantiate outer before inner. Accessed via o.getInner().x.

data.question: What is the purpose of the 'package' keyword in Java?
data.explanation: `package` groups related classes. Helps organize large codebases logically, such as `package com.myapp.models`.

data.topic: JVM, Memory Model, and Garbage Collection
data.question: What is the role of Garbage Collector in Java?
data.explanation: GC reclaims memory used by objects with no references. Triggered automatically or via System.gc().
`executeQuery()` runs a read-only SQL query. Results are accessed via ResultSet.
assertEquals verifies that 2+2 equals expected 4. Common in unit testing to validate logic.
`record` creates immutable data classes with auto-generated methods. Here, p.x() returns 1.

data.question:
What is the result?

IntStream.range(1, 4).map(x -> x * x).sum();
data.explanation: range(1,4) yields 1,2,3. Squares are 1,4,9 ‚Üí sum is 14. Demonstrates functional style processing.
If value is present, `orElse` returns it. Otherwise, it would fallback to "none".
Java 14 introduced switch expressions with return values. "B" matches case ‚Üí returns 2.

Polymorphism allows a subclass (Dog) to override methods of the superclass (Animal). The method invoked is determined at runtime. Examples: (1) Animal a = new Dog(); ‚Üí Dog, (2) Animal a = new Animal(); ‚Üí Animal, (3) Dog d = (Dog) a; ‚Üí valid cast, (4) a instanceof Dog ‚Üí true.

data.question: Which of the following is true about abstract classes in Java?
options: They must have all abstract methods
data.explanation: Abstract classes cannot be instantiated but can have constructors, concrete methods, and fields. Examples: abstract class A {} ‚Üí valid, A a = new A(); ‚Üí error, A() {} ‚Üí constructor.

data.question: Which access modifier enforces encapsulation best for class fields?
data.explanation: `private` restricts access to within the class. Encapsulation is achieved by hiding fields and providing public getters/setters. Examples: private int age; public int getAge(); public void setAge(int a);

data.question: Which of the following is a valid functional interface in Java?
data.explanation: A functional interface has exactly one abstract method. Runnable has run(). Examples: Runnable r = () -> {}; @FunctionalInterface interface X { void act(); }
Overloading chooses the most specific match. `print(5)` matches print(int). Examples: print(5.0) ‚Üí double, print('c') ‚Üí int, print(5L) ‚Üí error unless long exists.

data.question: Which keyword is used to call superclass constructor?
data.explanation: super() calls superclass constructor. Must be first in subclass constructor. Examples: super(); super(5); super.name.
Static members belong to the class, not instances. `x++` increments the shared field. Examples: A.x = 10; new A().x; main is static.
Constructor chaining using `this()` calls another constructor in the class. A() calls A(int). Result: x = 10.

data.question: What is true about default methods in interfaces?
data.explanation: Default methods were introduced in Java 8 to provide method bodies in interfaces. Allows backward compatibility.
Integer caching for values from -128 to 127 makes `a` and `b` refer to the same object. Use `equals()` for value comparison.
`Integer` objects are compared by reference with `==`. Values > 127 are not cached, so different objects. Use `.equals()` for value comparison.
`==` compares references. `new String()` creates a new object. Use `.equals()` for content comparison.
Primitive arrays are initialized with default values. `int` defaults to 0.
A return in `finally` overrides the `try` return. Execution always goes through finally.

data.question:
What happens with this code?

Integer.parseInt("012");
data.explanation: Java parses the string as decimal unless a radix is specified. `012` is not octal unless explicitly told.
Calling `.equals` on a null object causes a `NullPointerException`. Check for null before calling methods.
Without `break`, control falls through to the next case. Always use `break` unless fallthrough is desired.
`void A()` is a method, not a constructor. Java uses default constructor silently.
`b = true` assigns true to `b`, so the condition is always true. Common bug is confusing `=` with `==`.
Strings are immutable in Java. `concat()` returns a new string. `s` remains unchanged unless reassigned.
Java arrays are zero-indexed. Accessing index 3 in a 3-element array causes an exception.

data.question: Which modifier makes a method accessible only within its class?
data.explanation: `private` is the most restrictive access level, allowing visibility only within the same class.

data.question: Which of the following classes is immutable?
data.explanation: Strings are immutable. Any operation returns a new String object without altering the original.
Static variables are shared across all instances. The method `increment()` increases the same static variable.
`instanceof` checks object type. Every object in Java extends Object, so this is true.
Recursive factorial function: 3 * 2 * 1 = 6.
Casting from double to int truncates the decimal part. Value becomes 9.

data.question: Which statement is true?
options: Overloading can have different parameter types
data.response: Overloading can have different parameter types
data.explanation: Overloading means same method name but different parameter types. Overriding means same method signature in subclass.
`do-while` executes the body once before evaluating the condition, so it prints 1.

data.question: What does `final` on a method mean?
data.explanation: A method marked `final` cannot be overridden by subclasses. This preserves the implementation.
